sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Hi, I'm Dr. Alex Bomer, and I am the director of natural history here at On the Edge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So one stereotypically ugly animal within Europe I think really needs a lot more attention kind of paid to it is the angel shark.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They are, bless them, not the prettiest of sharks, but also because sharks naturally have this kind of air of scariness about them and elusiveness.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Angel sharks can be found all over Europe and they have an amazing role in their ecosystems.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Their ecosystems are very delicately balanced and them being a predator helped to continue to preserve that balance. But unfortunately, their numbers are dwindling because they're just not getting the time and attention that they deserve.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So let's take the example of bumblebees and wasps, for instance. Everyone looks at the bumblebee, this kind of fuzzy little pollinator that we really relate to its work ethic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And I think wasps becoming almost this nasty creature, this kind of annoyance was really because people didn't understand their role.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So we've almost created this villain-esque kind of imagineering about wasps, whereas we've reinvented that for bees who can also sting, choose not to as often, but because they are more cute, cuddly, and we see their role within our lives. So they're apex predators, so they help us with pest control. They get rid of caterpillars, spiders, green flies that kind of wreak havoc on crops and our gardens and they need our attention just as much as those cuddly little chunky bees and that we see campaigns about every day of the week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So PR for those animals that we find annoying or scary or irritating, we really just need to change the narrative. That's how we protect them but what On the Edge is really about is championing the underdogs and making those species that are on the brink of existence and there are no others like them visible to the rest of the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So what we do is we look at innovating means of storytelling to connect with a lot of different audiences.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We're taking a very broad stroke approach and really looking at telling stories about species that you just never heard of before.
